title: Bernard T. Espelage
text:
Bernard Theodore Espelage, <a href="Franciscan">O.F.M.</a> (February 16, 1892—February 19, 1971) was an American <a href="prelate">prelate</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. He was the first <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Gallup">Bishop of Gallup</a>, <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a> (1940-1969).
Biography.
Bernard Espelage was born in <a href="Cincinnati%2C%20Ohio">Cincinnati</a>, <a href="Ohio">Ohio</a>, to Bernard and Clara (née Schottelkotte) Espelage. He received his early education at <a href="parochial%20school">parochial school</a>s and <a href="Franciscan">Franciscan</a> <a href="Seminary">seminaries</a>. He was invested with the Franciscan <a href="Religious%20habit">habit</a> on August 15, 1910, and made his <a href="Profession%20%28religious%29">profession</a> as a member of the Franciscan Order on August 15, 1911. He was later <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> to the <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priesthood</a> in <a href="Oldenburg%2C%20Indiana">Oldenburg</a>, <a href="Indiana">Indiana</a>, on May 16, 1918.
He then served as a <a href="curate">curate</a> in <a href="Roswell%2C%20New%20Mexico">Roswell</a>, <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>, for a year before becoming <a href="Chancellor%20%28ecclesiastical%29">chancellor</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Santa%20Fe">Archdiocese of Santa Fe</a> in 1919. In 1926 he earned a <a href="Licentiate%20of%20Canon%20Law">Licentiate of Canon Law</a> from the <a href="The%20Catholic%20University%20of%20America">Catholic University of America</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> He served as <a href="Rector%20%28ecclesiastical%29">rector</a> of the <a href="Cathedral%20Basilica%20of%20St.%20Francis%20of%20Assisi">Cathedral of St. Francis of Assisi</a> (1934-1939) and afterwards returned to Oldenburg, where he was <a href="pastor">pastor</a> of <a href="http%3A//www.archindy.org/Parishes/listings/115.html">Holy Family Church</a> (1939-1940).
On July 20, 1940, Espelage was reassigned to New Mexico as the first <a href="Ordinary%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">Bishop</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Gallup">Diocese of Gallup</a> by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20XII">Pope Pius XII</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">episcopal</a> <a href="consecration">consecration</a> on the following October 9 from Archbishop <a href="John%20T.%20McNicholas">John T. McNicholas</a>, <a href="Dominican%20Order">O.P.</a>, with Bishop <a href="Joseph%20H.%20Albers">Joseph H. Albers</a> and Archbishop <a href="Joseph%20Ritter">Joseph Ritter</a> serving as <a href="Consecrator">co-consecrators</a>. He attended all four sessions of the <a href="Second%20Vatican%20Council">Second Vatican Council</a> between 1962 and 1965. During his 29-year-long tenure, he increased the number of Catholics from 30,000 to 79,260; priests from 32 to 108; and parishes from 17 to 53.
Espelage retired as Bishop of Gallup on August 25, 1969; he was named <a href="Titular%20Bishop">Titular Bishop</a> of "Penafiel" by <a href="Pope%20Paul%20VI">Pope Paul VI</a> on the same date. He later died at age 79.
